awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: ABI Development: An Integrated Platform for Retrieval, Visualization and Analysis of 3D Morphology From Digital Biological Collections
awd_abstract_narration:
The anatomical structure of an organism can provide important clues about its adaptation to its environment, its evolutionary history and its systematic relationships. The morphometric (quantitative) study of the organism's shape and function is typically conducted at natural history museums, by measuring the specimen directly. High-resolution 3D imaging techniques (e.g., micro computed tomography) provide us to capture the internal and external anatomy of biological specimens in unprecedented detail. Likewise, online virtual "collections" (e.g., MorphoSource) provide a convenient access to these datasets, without requiring scientists to travel to different museums to collect their data. However, the complex nature of these 3D datasets makes them challenging to analyze for most researchers. In this project, we propose to develop an open-source software to retrieve and visualize 3D biological specimens from online museums. We will also develop tools for the scientists to measure and analyze the anatomy more easily. 

Geometric Morphometrics Methods (GMM) are a set of quantitative analytical techniques that rely on landmarks to capture organismal shape and form. This project proposes to develop a GMM module for open-source 3D-Slicer (Slicer) visualization software as an integrated toolkit to address challenges researchers face working with 3D anatomical data. In addition to manual annotation of landmarks, the toolkit will provide two distinct (user-guided and automated) types of semi-landmarking methods to enable general purpose dense spatial sampling for different study designs. Annotated landmark data can be analyzed in the GMM module using the Generalized Procrustes Analysis (GPA). Shape variation associated with GPA can be decomposed as principal warps and can be visualized in full 3D. Toolkit will also provide a data aggregator (SpecMart) that will query online 3D specimen repository MorphoSource by taxonomy (and other tokens), retrieve and visualize data within Slicer. We will train students in theory and application of 3D image segmentation, analysis and visualization as it applies to nonmedical volumetric imaging datasets to facilitate reproducible and high-throughput analysis of such datasets. The toolkit will be developed as an add-on package to Slicer using open-source toolchains and software development platforms (such as git). The stable versions of the module will be distributed through Extension Manager of Slicer (and its online portal) and documentation will be hosted on their site. The open-source nature of this development and use of the Slicer community's existing infrastructure that has been in existence more than 15 years to distribute and support the toolkit will mean that the software will be widely available for many years to come and can be supported (and potentially expanded) by the user community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the years NSF Biology Directorate has made significant investments in the 3D digitization of the biological specimens in natural history collections. As part of these efforts tens of thousands of 3D scanned specimens were deposited into various online digital archives. These digitized specimens can be extremely useful in biological teaching (e.g., visualizing the diversity of life) or in research (e.g., study skeletal anatomy). However, while the contents of these 3D digital specimen archives were mostly public, interacting and using the data was not easy, and often required use of proprietary and expensive 3D visualization; which created barriers in science. Furthermore, these barriers limited the return on investment, as the reusability of these digital specimens in multiple contexts (outreach, teaching and research) was the primary argument for their creation in the first place.

To overcome this obstacle, and to truly make this invaluable data accessible to biologists, our project have developed the SlicerMorph, an extension for the free and  open-source biomedical visualization platform 3D Slicer. Slicer was already a very powerful software to visualize, segment and quantify 3D scans of humans and other organisms. However, the biology community considered the learning curve fairly steep and found the data import from microCT scanner, a tomographic imaging instrument that allows researchers acquire 3D images of organisms in much higher detail than clinical CT scanners, to be convoluted. In light of this, our project goals were to simplify the identified pain points identified, as well as increasing the knowledge base of the community through an extensive online and in-person training program.

During the four years, we held five week-long intense short courses on how to conduct digital morphology and morphometrics with SlicerMorph and trained over 200 participants mainly from biological sciences and related fields. Additionally, we have also presented nine half-day demos an workshops at professional society meetings, further training 250 attendees. As a group we have answered over 300 questions on the 3D Slicer forum related to 3D digital morphology and/or slicermorph utility. Through our interactions with the attendees at these workshops and short courses we had an in-depth understanding of what were the missing software features in Slicer platform for our community and implemented them as either part of the SlicerMorph extension (e.g., biology specific workflows), or worked with the core developers of Slicer to incorporate to the main application (e.g, functionality generally applicable to everyone). All of our source code is released under an open and permissive BSD license and can be found at https://github.com/SlicerMorph/SlicerMorph, and the standardized tutorials that cover all aspects of digital morphology is also publicly available at https://github.com/SlicerMorph/Tutorials. We encourage course instructors to incorporate these tutorials into their courses that rely on digital biodiversity specimens, and change them as they see fit.

Through SlicerMorph extension, 3D Slicer has now turned into a complete, turn-key solution for all tasks related to digital morphology starting from importing data from repositories, visualizing them, segmenting and quantifying them, making animations for scientific meetings, and exporting data into open-source data analytics platforms such as R or Python for domain-specific, specialized analyses. Since being made publicly available as part of the Slicer's extension catalog in 2020, our extension has been downloaded over 15,000, our online video tutorials (on youtube) cumulatively has been seen over 10,000 times. Additionally we have published four peer-reviewed articles that explained our software tools and applied the developed methodologies to real biological questions to demonstrate their applicability. While it has been less than two years since their publication, these papers have been cited more 30 times cumulatively.
